data.title: The Paleface | film by McLeod [1948]
data.meta_description: Other articles where The Paleface is discussed: Norman Z. McLeod: Danny Kaye and Bob Hope: …collaborated on the comedy western The Paleface (1948), with Jane Russell. After the Fred Astaire–Betty Hutton musical Let’s Dance (1950), McLeod reunited with Hope for My Favorite Spy (1951), a surprisingly nimble Cold War spoof, with Hedy Lamarr as the love interest.
data.text:
In Norman Z. McLeod: Danny Kaye and Bob Hope

…collaborated on the comedy western The Paleface (1948), with Jane Russell. After the Fred Astaire–Betty Hutton musical Let’s Dance (1950), McLeod reunited with Hope for My Favorite Spy (1951), a surprisingly nimble Cold War spoof, with Hedy Lamarr as the love interest.

Read More

In Bob Hope: Movies

… (1947), My Favorite Brunette (1947), The Paleface (1948), Fancy Pants (1950), The Lemon Drop Kid (1951), and Son of Paleface (1952). Several films also showcased Hope’s skills as a song-and-dance man and afforded him the opportunity to introduce many songs that became popular standards, including “Two Sleepy People,” “Buttons and…

In Jane Russell

…Hope in the box-office hit The Paleface (1948) and its sequel, Son of Paleface (1952). Both movies gave Russell an opportunity to show off her vocal skills; each garnered an Academy Award nomination for best song, with a win for “Buttons and Bows” from The Paleface. One of Russell’s best-known…
